intro: Plagiobothrys parishii, commonly known as the Parish's bladderpod, is a rare flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils in arid environments, such as grasslands and shrublands. It is distinguished by its inflated, bladder-like pods that encase its seeds. Due to habitat loss and limited distribution, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
